awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Assessment of Need for a National Center of AGEP Transformation Alliance Outcomes and Deliverables
awd_abstract_narration:
The project team is examining the needs of the NSF Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate’s (AGEP) Transformation Alliances for a national resource center that would include awardee data, tools, materials, and products. As institutions of higher education (IHEs) across our nation aim to reproduce the strategies and interventions that were developed, implemented, and studied by more than two dozen AGEP Transformation Alliances and over 100 awarded IHEs, it is necessary to make these resources available for broad dissemination.  Determining the needs for a national resource center of publicly available AGEP Transformation Alliance materials, offers to stimulate future community initiatives to create an information hub that will advance knowledge about broadening the participation of STEM graduate students, postdoctoral research scholars, and faculty who are members of racial and ethnic groups underrepresented in STEM.

The research team is conducting a series of surveys and interviews with the AGEP Transformation Alliance teams to assess the information materials from awards that were issued in response to the NSF AGEP Program Solicitations NSF 14-505 and NSF 16-552. It is urgent to conduct this assessment as some of the awards have already ended and others will soon expire. The investigators are examining the scope of materials, issues of licensing and privacy, use agreements, and the preservation needs for the material transfers. In addition to the initial surveys, interviews, and assessments, the project team will also gather input from a broader community of stakeholders, including but not limited to current and former awardees in the NSF INCLUDES and the NSF ADVANCE networks. Results from the project work will be shared with AGEP Transformation Alliances, other NSF AGEP awardees, and a broad group of interested people and organizations.

The award is funded by NSF's Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program, which supports STEM education research to increase the number of faculty who are members of racial and ethnic groups underrepresented in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The  project  addresses a significant gap in preserving and disseminating the valuable knowledge and resources generated by AGEP Alliances and grants. A tremendous number of deliverables in the form of videos, toolkits, data, annual reports, technical reports, presentations, etc. exist within each alliance which is either currently or will be inaccessible in the near future.

By conducting a needs assessment survey, to guide the development of a  deliverables resource center, the project aimed to lay the groundwork for a repository that would make this wealth of information accessible to future scholars and researchers, thus extending the impact of the NSF Division of Human Resource Development's investment in these programs. 

Our findings from the systematic study of the existing resources and community needs for archiving and preservation are essential for the development of a resource center. Given the enormous amount of information collected as a result of these and future projects, resource centers will be critical vehicles to access the grey literature created in the process of human resource development research. 

Specifically, we created and conducted a needs assessment survey to  lay the foundation for the creation of a deliverables resource center for the AGEP past awardees. The survey included questions addressing 1) what members in each Alliance want to and can share 2) what members in each alliance think is important to get out of a resource center and how they would like to use the materials 3) recommendations for the most effective organization accessible and access for the resource center. Zoom interviews were conducted following completion of the survey.

From the survey and interviews, we were able 1: Identify the scope of existing deliverables (print or electronic, content agnostic (i.e. reports, educational materials, marketing materials, communications, marketing, recruitment materials, records and historical archives, etc.) that Alliances feel should be archived.  2: Identify the terms of usage agreements and material transfer agreements for the individual Alliances. 3: Identify the design constraints desired by the Alliance members that will make the research center an accessible and enjoyable archive experience. 4: Synthesize the feedback from the Alliances and other stakeholders to set the stage for the development of a research center/repository. 

Intellectual Merit:  The Alliances have not had a comprehensive perspective of the entirety of the created body of knowledge that has been produced. By capturing an inventory of the existing materials at this point in time, and planning proactively to make the materials available to the scholarly community at large and the justice, equity, diversity and inclusion research community specifically, the research produced will have an extended impact on higher education. The white paper resulting from this work sets forth a plan for the development and implementation of repository that will facilitate Alliances materials to reach the larger audiences needed to realize their full promise and the proposed infrastructure will provide ongoing access and thus prevent the materials from being lost over time. Taking into account the findings of the work from this funding to establish a repository will provide a return on investment in terms of greater impact for the researchers in terms of citations and altMetrics, and for the National Science Foundation in terms of re-usage and access for long term programming. 

Broader Impacts:

The findings of the RAPID work hold significant potential for advancing the goal of increasing representation of underrepresented minorities (URM) in STEM fields. By assessing the need for a foundational research collection focused on increasing URM faculty representation in higher education, our work lays the groundwork for making valuable materials widely accessible in the following ways:

  1. Research Collection: The assessment provides a solid foundation for the development of a research collection focused on increasing URM faculty representation which could  serve as a valuable resource for scholars, practitioners, and policymakers interested in advancing diversity and inclusion in higher education.

  2. Broad Accessibility: Making these materials broadly available is crucial for maximizing their impact. Ensuring accessibility to the original researchers, as well as facilitating cross-institutional sharing and discovery by web-crawlers  enables broader dissemination and utilization of the findings.

  3. Professional Development: The availability of these materials for citation and use as professional development resources benefits both individual researchers and institutions seeking to enhance their diversity and inclusion efforts. 

  4. Citation and Recognition: Enabling the citation of these materials, facilitates the  recognition and acknowledgment of the work done in this area. This not only enhances the visibility and impact of the research but also encourages further scholarship and collaboration in the field of justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion (JEDI).

In sum, ithis work holds promise for advancing diversity and inclusion in STEM fields by recomending a strategy to ensure the availability and accessibility of foundational research materials. It represents a significant step toward achieving full participation of underrepresented minorities in higher education and beyond.

The white paper is available at https://docs.lib.purdue.edu/lib_fsdocs/283

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/18/2024
Modified by: Christie L Sahley
